prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
Aita for giving a woman a taste of her own behavior
I'm sitting at the airport and this older lady sat down right next to me and took her iPad out and starts watching a show quite loud. 

To me this is a foul in public however I just ignored it and put my earbuds in. 

After a while I made a phone call using my earbuds. Literally 30 seconds into my call she interrupts me and asks me to quit being rude and talk quietly so she can hear her show.

I was as polite as I could and said that not only herself but everyone for about 10 feet and I could hear her show word for word and that making a phone call isn't rude but watching a show on your device full volume in a public waiting area is actually very rude and that is why people use headphones. 

She said she has every right to enjoy her show without being interrupted by a rude and selfish phone call or having to use headphones. 

I said she was absolutely right and I am completely wrong, please enjoy your show while we  wait for the plane and I will do  the same.       I then proceeded to take out my iPad and open ice cubes good cop bad cop music video and play it full volume on my device without my earbuds. 

I have never seen someone storm off so mad. 


"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let me try to figure this out. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the story is in the wrong. The situation involves a disagreement at an airport between the author and an older lady.

First, the lady was watching a show on her iPad loudly in a public area. The author initially ignored it by putting in earbuds. Then, when the author made a phone call, the lady asked him to be quiet. The author responded by pointing out that her loud iPad was also rude. The lady defended her actions, and then the author escalated the situation by playing a music video full volume on his own device, causing her to storm off.

So, the key points here are about public behavior and mutual respect. The lady was indeed inconsiderate by using her device loudly without headphones, which is generally frowned upon in public spaces. The author's initial reaction was to point out her inconsiderate behavior, which seems reasonable. However, when she responded, the author escalated the situation by doing the same thing—playing his own device loudly. Even though the author might have felt wronged initially, retaliating in kind by making it worse could be seen as his mistake. 

The question is whether the author is in the wrong. While the lady started the problem, the author's response of playing loud music in retaliation might not be the right approach. Even if he was trying to make a point, escalating the conflict rather than de-escalating it can be considered wrong. Public settings require a certain level of decorum, and both parties have a responsibility to be considerate. The author had the opportunity to calmly explain his perspective and perhaps ask her to lower the volume without taking it to the next level. By playing his own device loudly, he mirrored her behavior, which might not be the appropriate way to handle the situation. 

On the other hand, the lady was in the wrong first, so there's a debate here. But generally, the principle is that responding with similar inconsiderate behavior isn't advisable. So, the author's action could be seen as equally wrong in the eyes of others present, even if he felt justified. The question is whether he's in the wrong. In many cases, the advice is to correct the behavior without reciprocating. Therefore, the author might be in the wrong for retaliating in a way that escalated the situation.
